description: The bat star is a seastar that comes in various colors: red, orange, yellow, brown, green, and purple.  The webbing between their arms makes them look similar to a pentagon. They can grow up to eight inches or 20 cm across and commonly have five arms. They use sensors at the end of their feet to “smell” their prey.

The knobby sea star also known as the “jeweled star” is a small sea star that is covered with blue and white nubs. To eat it extends its stomach outside of its mouth and digests its prey outside of its body.
The brittle star is a unique-looking sea star with a pentagonal disc and five long, slender arms. On each arm is a row of spines. It is often found in the middle or lower intertidal zone.

The ochre sea star is a large orange or purple sea star with a rough bumpy texture. It is commonly known as a “keystone species” which indicates the health of an intertidal zone. Although it is slow, it is considered the avid hunters of small animals.

The purple sea urchin looks like a donut without a hole, with long purple-red spines extending outward from its core. It moves with small tubular feet with suction cups to keep hold of surfaces. It eats algae, kelp, and dead matter.
The red sea urchin has long red spines pointing outward from its body. It is found on hard surfaces and in rocky reefs, and it can live for up to 100 years.

The abalone is a marine snail covered by a flattened spiral shell with a line of holes along one edge. It is known for its beautiful iridescent shell and pearls, which have been used in jewelry and art.

The California spiny lobster is found in the eastern Pacific Ocean, ranging from Monterey Bay, California, to the Gulf of Tehuantepec, Mexico. It typically grows to a length of over 12 inches (30 cm) and is reddish-brown with stripes along the legs. Some California spiny lobsters have been known to grow to 3 feet in length! It has a pair of enlarged antennae but no claws.
The California two-spot octopus can easily be identified by the blue spots under its eyes. They usually live for one to two years, and they can reach up to 23 inches long when fully outstretched.

The California sea hare is a sea slug that can get huge and weigh up to 35 pounds! It comes in various colors, usually shades of red and brown and it has antennas on the top of its head. It is a herbivore who enjoys feeding on algae.

The Spanish shawl is a super colorful sea slug. It has a purple body and an orange mohawk on its back. The mohawk is made up of cerata, organs that help the slug breathe. When being hunted by other predators, it can move away by flexing its body and pushing off the water.

The Hopkins’ rose is a pink sea slug known as a nudibranch. It is carnivorous, feeding on bryozoans. It has gills on the outside of its body. What’s interesting is that “nudibranch” actually translates to naked gill!
The red sponge dorid is a bright reddish-orange nudibranch, which is a species of sea slug. It is a dorid nudibranch, which means it uses gills, located on their backs, to draw oxygen from the water.

The California aglaja is a large sea slug that is covered in yellow streaks, and lines of blue dots. It feasts on snails and small fish, and it uses slime trails to ward off predators. It does not possess organs that allow them to see.

The Zebra perch is a football-shaped fish with a spikey fin on top and a short tail. Its most notable feature and its namesake comes from its black and white vertical striping. It primarily eats red algae.

The opaleye is a football-shaped fish with a dull green-gray color, easily identified by the white spots on its back near the fins. It primarily feeds on algae. The opaleye can also breathe air when out of water, allowing it to survive for a time when exposed during low tide.

The Giant kelpfish is a long thin fish with two small long fins near its head, a short dorsal fin that extends the length of its body, and a bottom fin from mid-length to tail. The shape of its body helps them blend into the kelp. It can change its color to better match its surroundings.

Several species of sculpins live in our local tidepools. These fish are well camouflaged, often blending in well with rocks and sand. They can sit very still, perched on their fins. Most sculpins have spiky fins and bodies. Occasionally, they are mistaken for small sharks
